Body:
BC-SPOT-BJT17-COX 
    

 UPDATE      UPDATE
      EDS: Adds: BIDIS-STUDY, FOOD-ILLNESS
      
      The Cox News Service spot news budget for Friday, Sept. 17,
1999.
      c.1999 Cox News Service

   Photo and graphics information and editors' names can be found
at the end of this budget.

   HURRICANE FLOYD

   FLOYD-MAIN _ Lead news story on damage from Hurricane Floyd,
which slammed into North Carolina early Thursday morning. (Staff,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   EDs: Later budgets will include sidebar information.

   FLOYD-NYC _ NEW YORK _ The scene in the Garment District as
Manhattan empties out before Hurricane Floyd hits at rush hour.
(Walton, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   w/FLOYD-RETURN _ A look at the scene at the Dublin, Ga., exit on
I-16 as evacuees return to the coast. Tales of two days spent with
friends and relatives or nightmares of sleeping in parking lots,
worrying about whether the beach and their homes are still there.
What did the motel and convenience store operators have to say
about business with all these folks coming and going? (Atlanta
Journal-Constitution).

   FLOYD-NC _ Wrightsville Beach _ Why don't these people move?
North Carolina's coastline has been battered this decade, with two
hurricanes in two weeks and five in the past three years. A look at
the what Floyd wrought in North Carolina, from Cape Fear up through
the Outer Banks and what state and federal officials are saying
about what changes may need to be made regarding insurance,
building restrictions and emergency procedures. (Burritt, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution).

   FLOYD-COMMERCE _ Trying for a by the numbers look at how much
businesses like Little General, Waffle House, Days Inn and Home
Depot gained from Floyd, and how much was lost by Disney World,
Charleston horse-drawn carriage operators and other tourism sites.
(Poole, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   FLOYD-BAHAMAS _ (DATELINE TO COME), Bahamas _ The remote islands
of the Bahamas suffered widespread damage as a result of Hurricane
Floyd. The loss of communications in the hardest-hit areas has
delayed damage reports, but Cox Caribbean correspondent Mike
Williams and a Palm Beach Post photographer have managed to reach
some of these distant islands. (Williams, Cox News Service). 30.

   EDs: A small plane is to pick them (or their copy/photos) up at
5 p.m. EDT and return to West Palm Beach. Story will be moved by
the Palm Beach Post.

   FLOYD-HITECH _ All the technology in the world doesn't help when
the electricity is out and you're in a dead area and nowhere near a
cell tower. Technology keeps advancing to new heights with
cellphones and Palm Pilots and digital two-way beepers, but when a
hurricane hits, it's still best to have a transitor radio. (Husted,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   w/Techno Buddy sig.

   OLYMPICS

   OLY-NEWREPORT _ The amended Atlanta Olympic report on excesses
in winning the bid is released today. Billy Payne, who prepared the
original (incomplete and partly inaccurate) report, and former U.S.
Attorney Griffin Bell, who prepared the revised report, are
scheduled to hold an afternoon news conference to discuss it.
(Turner, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 30. WITH PHOTO.

   w/OLY-ANALYSIS _ An analytical breakdown of the report, which
details gifts, transportation, educational opportunities, travel --
all perks for IOC members and their families. The sum of the
excesses makes it clear that Atlanta Olympic officials were less
than truthful in categorizing their tactics as ``southern
hospitality.'' (Turner, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 50.

   OLY-HOSTS _ Joe and Patty Thomas, according to ACOG memos, were
advised to ``invite the wildest people'' they knew for a dinner
party and include a trip to a strip club after desert. ``I almost
wish it was that colorful,'' says Joe Thomas. The dinners were
sedate, the Thomases say. And such suggestions were made tongue in
cheek. (CWilliams, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 10.

   OLY-CHRONOLOGY _ A chronology since the Salt Lake scandal broke,
interspersed with quotes from Atlanta officials through the year
(Staff, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 52.

   w/file art

   OLY-RULES _ The IOC rules on gifts. (Staff)10''

   OLY-SUIT _ Where the Open Records suit stands in light of
today's report (Staff, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 10.

   OLY-GIFTS _ Lists of gifts, travel, etc. for each member.
(Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   TEXAS SHOOTING

   SHOOTING-BUSH _ FORT WORTH, Texas _ Saying there is ``wave of
evil'' sweeping the country, GOP presidential front-runner George
W. Bush cut short a campaign trip to Michigan to fly home and offer
what comfort he could to the victims of the church shooting and
their families. The visit and the incident pose potential political
problems for Gov. Bush: the visit because it opens him to charges
of political opportunism and the incident because it puts the
spotlight on his views about gun rights. (Herman, Austin
American-Statesman) 20.

   w/SHOOTING-GUNS _ AUSTIN, Texas _ The Fort Worth church shooting
is sure to reignite debate on gun laws in Texas and around the
nation, particularly in the presidential election campaign. This
story is a look at the state of Texas' gun laws, how they compare
with those around the country and talk to presidential candidates
and political interest groups about what's next in light of the
spate of recent national shootings. (Greenberger, Austin
American-Statesman). 15-20.

   SHOOTING-GUNSTANDS _ AUSTIN _ A list of where the presidential
candidates stand on gun control. (Greenberger, Austin
American-Statesman).

   SHOOTING-RENO _ WASHINGTON _ Attorney General Janet Reno said
Thursday that Americans must ``come together'' and deal with issues
of guns, mental illness and hate to stop such tragedies as the
shooting in a Fort Worth church. (Dart, Cox News Service). 15.

   POLITICS

   LIDDY-DOLE _ JACKSONVILLE _ Out the windows of the swank River
Club, the first distant signs of Hurricane Floyd were taking shape
on the horizon Monday as Elizabeth Dole and Rep. Tillie Fowler
worked the tables at a $500-a-plate luncheon fund-raiser. It was a
fitting backdrop for a candidate who touts her leadership of one of
the world's premier disaster relief organizations, the American Red
Cross, as part of a long list of credentials. (Baxter, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED

   INTERNET-POLITICS _ WASHINGTON _ A unique four-hour online
seminar Thursday reviews the state of online presidential politics.
We'll monitor and report. (Glass, Cox News Service).

   Moving in (w) Washington and (p) politics categories.

   INTERNATIONAL

   RUSSIA-BOMB _ MOSCOW _ A bomb planted inside a truck ripped
apart an apartment building in southern Russia early Thursday,
killing at least 17 people and wounding more than 100. It was the
fourth bomb attack on an apartment block in Russia in the past two
weeks _ attacks widely blamed on Islamic militants _ that have
killed nearly 300. The bombings have fueled speculation in Moscow
that Prime Minister Vladimir Putin or President Boris Yeltsin could
be forced to resign if the wave of terror continues. (Holmes, Cox
News Service).

   MEXICO-MASSIEU _ MEXICO CITY _ With a fatal overdose of Zoloft
anti-depressants, Mario Ruiz Massieu beat his rap against explosive
charges of drug trafficking involving the highest levels of the
Mexican government. Many Mexicans in this highly suspicious country
will probably forever wonder if Ruiz Massieu really took his own
life. The former Mexican drug prosecutor _ accused of accepting
drug money bribes _ was about to go to trial in the United States
in a case that could have revealed more sordid secrets of
corruption during the presidency of Carlos Salinas de Gortari.
``Death defeats justice,'' one newspaper here said of Ruiz
Massieu's suicide on Wednesday in New Jersey. (Ferriss, Cox News
Service). 25.

   MEXICO-VIRGIN _ MEXICO CITY _ The Mother of Mexico is becoming
the mother of all election squabbles. Mexico's ruling party has
filed an official elections commission complaint that its
presidential rival Vicente Fox unlawfully used this country's most
sacred religious and cultural symbol _ the Virgin of Guadalupe _
for political gain. At a recent rally Fox's children gave him a
banner of the Virgin and he unfurled it before a crowd. A strong
conservative party contender for the presidency in Mexico's July
2000 elections, Fox has since publicly said he would ``carry the
Virgin in my heart'' but leave her home when out on the campaign
trail. But Fox's rivals won't leave the issue alone. (Ferriss, Cox
News Service). 20.

   NATIONAL

   WACO-LAWSUIT _ WACO, Texas _ Daily coverage leading up to the
opening of the civil trial Oct. 18. (Waco Tribune-Herald).

   WASHINGTON

   Y2K-OVERSEAS _ WASHINGTON _ Earlier this week when the State
Department released its assessment of how well other countries are
handling Y2K computer problems, it refused to rank nations
according to risk, saying its evaluations were intended to only
``help Americans make their own decisions'' about year-end travel.
But with Jan. 1 just 15 weeks away, U.S. tourists and business
travelers must soon decide whether to curtail overseas travel when
the year rolls over to 2000. Should U.S. companies, such as Delta
Air Lines, continue to send workers and passengers into Moscow when
the State Department says ``Y2K disruptions are likely to occur in
key sectors of electrical power, heat, telecommunications,
transportation, and financial and emergency services'' ? (Geewax,
Cox News Service). 20.

   EDs: Moving in (w) Washington, (f) financial and (i)
international categories.

   SCIENCE/MEDICINE

   FOOD-ILLNESS _ATLANTA _ Americans have always assumed that our
food supply is safe, but the constant reports of salmonella and E.
coli outbreaks are beginning to raise eyebrows and questions. With
good reason - a new report on foodborne disease by the CDC, the
most comprehensive yet done, reveals that the microbes cause 76
million cases of mild illness, 325,00hospitalizations, and 5,000
deaths in the US every year. (McKenna, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   BIDIS-STUDY _ATLANTA _ The first study to measure teens' use of
the hand-wrapped, scented cigarettes called ``bidis'' sounds a
warning bell: almost one out of every five male high school
students and one out of every eight female students have tried
them, and 13 percent of kids who smoke them think they are safer
than cigarettes. in fact, says the CDC, they're much more dangerous
- and if serious health effects including heart disease and cancer
are to be averted, action against the Indian imports must be taken
right away. (McKenna, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   COXNET BUDGET INFORMATION FOR SUBSCRIBERS OF THE NYT NEWS
SERVICE

   Spot news budgets move daily at 2 p.m. and 6 p.m. Eastern.
Additionally, separate features and commentary budgets move at 10
a.m., and sports and business budgets at 6 p.m. Additional updates
are possible if news developments warrant.

   All times are Eastern unless otherwise noted. PLEASE NOTE:
SPORTS STORIES will have an E.T.A. of 9:30 P.M. If news, business
or features stories will move after 8 p.m., an ETA will be given.

   PHOTOS, LAYOUTS and GRAPHICS

   CoxNet layouts are for sale over the web, through the New York
Times News Service's PageExpress service, at
www.nytsyn/pageexpress.

   If a budget line or story is marked with photos or graphics,
those are available from the New York Times News Service at
212-556-4204. Or call CoxNet for more information at 404-526-5456.

   HOW TO REACH US

   Questions should be directed to CoxNet, the Cox News Service, in
Atlanta at 404-526-5456. We are staffed 8 a.m. to 10 p.m.
Monday-Friday, and 1-10 p.m. on weekends and holidays.

   The news manager is Paul Foutch, 404-526-5429,
pfoutch(at)coxnews.com.

   The day news editor is Tom Oder, 404-526-5887,
toder(at)coxnews.com.

   The night news editor is Todd C. Duncan, 404-582-7282,
tduncan(at)coxnews.com.

   Cox Washington Bureau:

   News editor Art Dalglish, 202-887-8338, artd(at)coxnews.com

   Foreign editor Rick Christie, 202-887-8316, rickc(at)coxnews.com

   Bureau chief Andy Alexander, 202-887-8334, andya(at)coxnews.com

   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers

   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service
